Robinson]] with saving his career following his eclipse in the [[Hollywood blacklist]].{{sfn|Presley|Vieira|2014|p=375}} ===Style and themes=== Cecil B. DeMille's film production career evolved from critically significant silent films to financially significant sounds films. He began his career with reserved yet brilliant melodramas. From there, DeMille's style developed into marital comedies with outrageously melodramatic plots.{{sfn|Eyman|2010|p=5}} In order to attract a high-class audience, DeMille based many of his early films on stage melodramas, novels, and short stories.{{sfn|Higashi|1994|p=2}} He began the production of epics earlier in his career until they began to solidify his career in the 1920s. By 1930, DeMille had perfected his film style of mass-interest spectacle films with Western, Roman, or Biblical themes.{{sfn|Eyman|2010|p=5}} DeMille was often criticized for making his spectacles too colorful and for being too occupied with entertaining the audience rather than accessing the artistic and auteur possibilities that film could provide. However, others interpreted DeMille's work as visually impressive, thrilling, and nostalgic. Along the same lines, critics of DeMille often qualify him by his later spectacles and fail to consider several decades of ingenuity and energy that defined him during his generation.{{sfn|Eyman|2010|p=5}} Throughout his career, he did not alter his films to better adhere to contemporary or popular styles.{{sfn|Eyman|2010|pp=5–6}} Actor Charlton Heston admitted DeMille was, "terribly unfashionable" and [[Sidney Lumet]] called Demille, "the cheap version of [[D.W. Griffith]]," adding that DeMille, "[didn't have]...an original thought in his head," though Heston added that DeMille was much more than that.{{sfn|Eyman|2010|p=6}} [[File:Cecil-b-demille paramount-pictures.jpg|thumb|Cecil B. DeMille at Paramount Pictures|alt=DeMille posing on a chair with a pen in hand]] According to Scott Eyman, DeMille's films were at the same time masculine and feminine due to his thematic adventurousness and his eye for the extravagant.{{sfn|Eyman|2010|p=6}} DeMille's distinctive style can be seen through camera and lighting effects as early as ''The Squaw Man'' with the use of daydream images; moonlight and sunset on a mountain; and side-lighting through a tent flap.{{sfn|Louvish|2007|p=64}} In the early age of cinema, DeMille differentiated the Lasky Company from other production companies due to the use of dramatic, low-key lighting they called "Lasky lighting" and marketed as "[[Rembrandt lighting]]" to appeal to the public. DeMille achieved international recognition for his unique use of lighting and color tint in his film ''The Cheat''.{{harvnb|Higashi|1994|p=3}}; {{harvnb|Eames|1985|p=11}} DeMille's 1956 version of ''The Ten Commandments'', according to director Martin Scorsese, is renowned for its level of production and the care and detail that went into creating the film. He stated that ''The Ten Commandments'' was the final culmination of DeMille's style.{{sfn|Eyman|2010|p=478}} DeMille was interested in art and his favorite artist was [[Gustave Doré]]; DeMille based some of his most well-known scenes on the work of Doré.{{sfn|Presley|Vieira|2014|p=11}} DeMille was the first director to connect art to filmmaking; he created the title of "art director" on the film set.{{sfn|Presley|Vieira|2014|p=16}} DeMille was also known for his use of special effects without the use of digital technology. Notably, DeMille had cinematographer [[John P. Fulton]] create the [[Crossing the Red Sea|parting of the Red Sea]] scene in his 1956 film ''The Ten Commandments'', which was one of the most expensive special effects in film history, and has been called by [[Steven Spielberg]] "the greatest special effect in film history". The actual parting of the sea was created by releasing 360,000 gallons of water into a huge water tank split by a U-shaped trough, overlaying it with film of a giant waterfall that was built on the Paramount backlot, and playing the clip backwards.{{cite news |last1=Townsend |first1=Allie |title=A Brief History of Movie Special Effects |url=http://content.time.com/time/photogallery/0,29307,2055255_2247304,00.html |accessdate=July 2, 2019 |work=Time |publisher=Time, Inc.}}The Ten Commandments (Documentary: “Making Miracles”) (Six-Disc Limited Edition Blu-Ray/DVD Combo) Cecil B. DeMille / Paramount. Hollywood, California: Paramount Pictures.2011 Aside from his Biblical and historical epics which are concerned with how man relates to God, some of DeMille's films contained themes of "neo-naturalism" which portray the conflict between the laws of man and the laws of nature.{{cite news |last1=Watkins |first1=Daniel |title="Reap the Wild Wind"...or Don't: Cecil B. DeMille, the Evolving Neo-Naturalist |url=https://mubi.com/notebook/posts/reap-the-wild-windor-dont-cecil-b-demille-the-evolving-neo-naturalist |accessdate=June 20, 2019 |work=Notebook |publisher=MUBI |date=March 10, 2015}} Although he is known for his later "spectacular" films, his early films are held in high regard by critics and film historians. DeMille discovered the possibilities of the "bathroom" or "boudoir" in film without being "vulgar" or "cheap".{{sfn|Ringgold|Bodeen|1969|p=5}} DeMille's films ''Male and Female'', ''[[Why Change Your Wife?]]'', and ''The Affairs of Anatol'' can be retrospectively described as [[camp (style)|high camp]] and are categorized as "early DeMille films" due to their particular style of production and costume and set design. However, his earlier films ''The Captive'', ''[[Kindling (film)|Kindling]]'', ''[[Carmen (1915 Cecil B. DeMille film)|Carmen]]'', and ''[[The Whispering Chorus]]'' are more serious films.{{sfn|Ringgold|Bodeen|1969|p=5}} It is difficult to typify DeMille's films into one specific genre. His first three films were Westerns, and he filmed many Westerns throughout his career. However, throughout his career, he filmed comedies, periodic and contemporary romances, dramas, fantasies, propaganda, Biblical spectacles, musical comedies, suspense, and war films. At least one DeMille film can represent each film genre.{{sfn|Ringgold|Bodeen|1969|p=5}} DeMille produced the majority of his films before the 1930s, and by the time sound films were invented, film critics saw DeMille as antiquated, with his best filmmaking years behind him.{{sfn|Louvish|2007|pp=xiv–xv}} DeMille's film contained a number of similar themes throughout his career. However, the films of his silent era were often thematically different than the films of his sound era. His silent era films often included the "battle of the sexes" theme due to the era of women's suffrage and the enlarging role of women in society.{{sfn|Louvish|2007|p=69}} Moreover, before his religious-themed films, many of his silent era films revolved around "husband-and-wife-divorce-and-remarry satires", considerably more adult-themed. According to Simon Louvish, these films reflected DeMille's inner thoughts and opinions about marriage and human sexuality.{{sfn|Louvish|2007|pp=xv-xvi}} Religion was a theme that DeMille returned to throughout his career. Of his seventy films, five revolved around stories of the Bible and the New Testament; however many others, while not direct retellings of Biblical stories, had themes of faith and religious fanaticism in films such as ''The Crusades'' and ''The Road to Yesterday''.{{sfn|Louvish|2007|p=xiv}} Western and frontier American were also themes that DeMille returned to throughout his career. His first several films were westerns and he produced a chain of westerns during the sound era. Instead of portraying the danger and anarchy of the West, he portrayed the opportunity and redemption found in Western America.{{sfn|Louvish|2007|p=340}} Another common theme in DeMille's films is the reversal of fortune and the portrayal of the rich and the poor, including the war of the classes and man versus society conflicts such as in ''The Golden Chance'' and ''The Cheat''.{{sfn|Louvish|2007|pp=81, 111, 178}} In relation to his own interests and sexual preferences, [[sadomasochism]] was a minor theme present in some of his films.{{sfn|Louvish|2007|pp=90, 255}} Another minor characteristic of DeMille's films include train crashes which can be found in several of his films.{{sfn|Louvish|2007|p=402}} ==Legacy== [[File:Charlton Heston in The Ten Commandments film trailer.jpg|thumb|Charlton Heston as Moses in ''The Ten Commandments'' which is the eighth highest grossing film in the world, adjusted for inflation.|alt=Actor playing Moses wearing a red robe and holding his arms out to the sides with dark clouds behind him]]Known as the father of the Hollywood motion picture industry, Cecil B. DeMille made 70 films including several box-office hits. DeMille is one of the more commercially successful film directors in history{{harvnb|Ringgold|Bodeen|1969|p=5}}; {{harvnb|Presley|Vieira|2014|p=12}} with his films before the release of ''The Ten Commandments'' estimated to have grossed $650 million worldwide.{{cite magazine|title=Dirt is Not Necessarily Paydirt|magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=January 25, 1956|page=3|url=http://www.archive.org/stream/variety201-1956-01#page/n676/mode/1up|via=[[Archive.org]]}} Adjusted for inflation, DeMille's remake of ''The Ten Commandments'' is the eighth highest-grossing film in the world.{{cite book |title=Guinness World Records |edition=2015 |year=2014 |volume=60 |isbn=9781908843708 |pages=160–161|last1=Records |first1=Guinness World }} According to Sam Goldwyn, critics did not like DeMille's films, but the audiences did and "they have the final word".{{sfn|Presley|Vieira|2014|p=14}} Similarly, scholar David Blanke, argued that DeMille had lost the respect of his colleagues and film critics by his late film career. However, his final films maintained that DeMille was still respected by his audiences.{{sfn|Blanke|2018|p=300}} Five of DeMille's film were the highest-grossing films at the year of their release, with only Spielberg topping him with six of his films as the highest-grossing films of the year. DeMille's highest-grossing films include: ''The Sign of the Cross'' (1932), ''Unconquered'' (1947), ''Samson and Delilah'' (1949), ''The Greatest Show on Earth'' (1952), and ''The Ten Commandments'' (1956).{{cite web |last=Dirks |first=Tim |website=[[Filmsite.org]] |publisher=[[AMC Networks|American Movie Classics]] |title=All-Time Box-Office Hits By Decade and Year |url=http://www.filmsite.org/boxoffice2.html |accessdate=January 5, 2012}} Director [[Ridley Scott]] has been called "the Cecil B. DeMille of the digital era" due to his classical and medieval epics.{{cite news |last1=Pulver |first1=Andrew |title=Ridley Scott: from Alien to Exodus, a Cecil B. DeMille for the digital age |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/nov/28/ridley-scott-alien-exodus-film |accessdate=June 21, 2019 |work=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News & Media Limited |date=November 28, 2014}} Despite his box-office success, awards, and artistic achievements, DeMille has been dismissed and ignored by critics both during his life and posthumously. He consistently was criticized for producing shallow films without talent or artistic care. Compared to other directors, few film scholars have taken the time to academically analyze his films and style. During the [[French New Wave]], critics began to categorize certain filmmakers as [[auteur]]s such as [[Howard Hawks]], [[John Ford]], and [[Raoul Walsh]]. DeMille was left off the list, determined to be too unsophisticated and antiquated to be considered an auteur.{{sfn|Louvish|2007|p=270}} However, [[Simon Louvish]] wrote "he was the complete master and auteur of his films"{{sfn|Louvish|2007|p=xvii}} and Anton Kozlovic called him the "unsung American auteur". [[Andrew Sarris]], a leading proponent of the auteur theory, ranked DeMille highly as an auteur in the "Far Side of Paradise", just below the "Pantheon". Sarris added that despite the influence of styles of contemporary directors throughout his career, DeMille's style remained unchanged. [[Robert Birchard]] wrote one could argue auteurship of DeMille on the basis that DeMille's thematic and visual style remained consistent throughout his career. However, Birchard acknowledged that Sarris's point was more likely that DeMille's style was behind the development of film as an art form.{{sfn|Birchard|2004|p=xii}} Meanwhile, Sumiko Higashi sees DeMille as "not only a figure who was shaped and influenced by the forces of his era but as a filmmaker who left his own signature on the [[culture industry]]."{{sfn|Williams|2014|p=355}} The critic [[Camille Paglia]] has called ''The Ten Commandments'' one of the ten greatest films of all time.{{cite web |url=http://old.bfi.org.uk/sightandsound/topten/poll/voter.php?forename=Camille&surname=Paglia |title=BFI - Sight & Sound - Top Ten Poll 2002 - How the directors and critics voted |last=James |first=Nick |displayauthors=etal |publisher= |access-date=July 19, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160915132021/http://old.bfi.org.uk/sightandsound/topten/poll/voter.php?forename=Camille&surname=Paglia |archive-date=September 15, 2016 |url-status=dead }}[[File:Cecil b de mille directing.png|240px|thumb|DeMille directing, 1920|alt=DeMille on a stand, holding a megaphone, giving commands to crew members which surround him and several film cameras]] DeMille was one of the first directors to become a celebrity in his own right.{{cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/cecil-b-demille-accepted-golden-globe-named-him-1952-1161366|title=Hollywood Flashback: Cecil B. DeMille Accepted the Golden Globe Named for Him in 1952|last1=Higgins|first1=Bill|date=November 25, 2018|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=June 21, 2019|publisher=The Hollywood Reporter}} He cultivated the image of the omnipotent director,{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/jan/15/reel-dictators-why-despots-love-directors-lost-in-karastan|title=Reel dictators: why despots love directors|last1=Hoad|first1=Phil|date=January 15, 2016|work=The Guardian|accessdate=June 21, 2019|publisher=Guardian News & Media Limited}} complete with [[megaphone]], [[riding crop]], and [[jodhpurs]].{{cite news|url=https://www.lamag.com/askchris/displa-case-45-cecil-b-demilles-riding-crop/|title=Disp L.A. Case #45: Cecil B. DeMille's Riding Crop|last1=Nichols|first1=Chris|date=February 16, 2013|work=LA Magazine|accessdate=June 21, 2019|publisher=Los Angeles Magazine}}{{cite news|url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1997-sep-21-me-34726-story.html|title=Echoes of Epics in DeMille's Paradise|last1=Rasmussen|first1=Cecelia|date=September 21, 1997|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=June 21, 2019}} He was known for his unique, working wardrobe which included riding boots, riding pants, and soft, open necked shirts.{{sfn|Eyman|2010|p=64}} [[Joseph Henabery]] recalled that DeMille looked like "a king on a throne surrounded by his court" while directing films on a camera platform.{{sfn|Eyman|2010|p=147}} DeMille was respected by his peers, yet his individual films were sometimes criticized. "Directorially, I think his pictures were the most horrible things I've ever seen in my life", said director [[William Wellman]]. "But he put on pictures that made a fortune. In that respect, he was better than any of us," Wellman added.Brownlow, K. (1976). ''The Parade's Gone by...'' Berkeley, California: University of California Press. p. 185. {{ISBN|978-0-520-03068-8}}. Producer David O. Selznick wrote: "There has appeared only one Cecil B. DeMille. He is one of the most extraordinarily able showmen of modern times. However much I may dislike some of his pictures, it would be very silly of me, as a producer of commercial motion pictures, to demean for an instant his unparalleled skill as a maker of mass entertainment."Presley, ''Cecil B. DeMille'', p. 357. [[Salvador Dalí]] wrote that DeMille, [[Walt Disney]] and the [[Marx Brothers]] were "the three great American [[Surrealism|Surrealists]]".{{sfn|King|2007|p=59}} DeMille appeared as himself in numerous films, including the MGM comedy ''[[Free and Easy (1930 film)|Free and Easy]].''{{sfn|Birchard|2004|p=374}} He often appeared in his coming-attraction trailers and narrated many of his later films,{{sfn|Eyman|2010|pp=7–8}} even stepping on screen to introduce ''The Ten Commandments''.{{cite news |last1=Thomas |first1=Kevin |title=DeMille's Re-Released 'Commandments'--Better Than Ever |url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1990-05-16-ca-43-story.html |accessdate=June 25, 2019 |work=Los Angeles Times |date=May 16, 1990}} DeMille was immortalized in [[Billy Wilder]]'s ''[[Sunset Boulevard (film)|Sunset Boulevard]]'' when Gloria Swanson spoke the line: "All right, Mr. DeMille. I'm ready for my close-up." DeMille plays himself in the film.{{sfn|Eyman|2010|pp=1–2}} DeMille's reputation had a renaissance in the 2010s.{{cite news|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/sns-201412181600--tms--lizsmittr--x-a20141219-20141219-story.html|title=Cecil B. DeMille -- the greatest filmmaking showman rediscovered!|author=Liz Smith and the Tribune Content Agency|date=December 19, 2014|work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=June 22, 2019|publisher=Chicago Tribune}} As a filmmaker, DeMille was the aesthetic inspiration of many directors and films due to his early influence during the crucial development of the film industry. DeMille's early silent comedies influenced the comedies of [[Ernst Lubitsch]] and Charlie Chaplin's ''[[A Woman of Paris]]''. Additionally, DeMille's epics such as ''The Crusades'' influenced [[Sergei Eisenstein]]'s ''[[Alexander Nevsky (film)|Alexander Navsky]]''. Moreover, DeMille's epics inspired directors such as Howard Hawks, [[Nicholas Ray]], [[Joseph L. Mankiewicz]], and [[George Stevens]] to try producing epics.{{sfn|Eyman|2010|p=6}} Cecil B. DeMille has influenced the work of several well-known directors. [[Alfred Hitchcock]] cited DeMille's 1921 film ''[[Forbidden Fruit (1921 film)|Forbidden Fruit]]'' as an influence of his work and one of his top ten favorite films.{{cite web |last1=Mantgani |first1=Ian |title=10 Great Films that Influenced Alfred Hitchcock |url=https://www.bfi.org.uk/news-opinion/news-bfi/lists/10-great-films-influenced-alfred-hitchcock |website=BFI Film Forever |publisher=British Film Institute |accessdate=May 28, 2019}} DeMille has influenced the careers of many modern directors. Martin Scorsese cited ''Unconquered'', ''Samson and Delilah'', and ''The Greatest Show on Earth'' as DeMille films that have imparted lasting memories on him.{{sfn|Presley|Vieira|2014|p=6}} Scorsese admitted to having viewed ''The Ten Commandments'' forty or fifty times.{{cite book |editor1-last=Sobchack |editor1-first=Vivian |title=The Persistence of History: Cinema, Television, and the Modern Event |date=1996 |publisher=Routledge |location=New York |isbn=0415910846 |page=112 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=1OFHKste50QC&pg=PA111&lpg=PA111&dq=tim+burton+cecil+b+demille+influence#v=snippet&q=Martin%20Sco&f=false |accessdate=June 21, 2019}} Famed director Steven Spielberg stated that DeMille's ''The Greatest Show on Earth'' was one of the films that influenced him to become a filmmaker.{{sfn|Presley|Vieira|2014|p=8}} Furthermore, DeMille influenced about half of Spielberg's films, including ''[[War of the Worlds (2005 film)|War of the Worlds]]''.{{sfn|Eyman|2010|p=6}}{{refn|group=note|DeMille had considered making the film himself. He bought the rights to the novel in 1925, but abandoned the project in pre-production.{{cite book |last1=Flynn |first1=John L. |title=War of the Worlds: From Wells to Spielberg |date=2005 |publisher=Galactic Books |location=Owings Mills, Maryland |page=56 |isbn=0976940000 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=T0aCSs1-23sC&pg=PA56&lpg=PA56&dq=cecil+b+demille+%22war+of+the+worlds%22#v=onepage&q=cecil%20b%20demille%20%22war%20of%20the%20worlds%22&f=false |accessdate=July 1, 2019}}}} ''The Ten Commandments'' inspired [[DreamWorks Animation]]'s later film about Moses, ''[[The Prince of Egypt]]''.{{cite web | url=http://www.assistnews.net/strategic/s0000023.htm | title=Dan Wooding's strategic times | publisher=Assistnews.net | accessdate=March 3, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030329004351/http://assistnews.net/strategic/s0000023.htm|archivedate=March 29, 2003}} As one of the establishing members of the Paramount Pictures and co-founder of Hollywood, DeMille had a role in the development of the film industry.{{cite journal |last1=Kozlovic |first1=Anton Karl |title=Samson as a Moses-Figure in Cecil B. DeMille's "Samson and Delilah" (1949) |journal=Americana e-Journal of American Studies in Hungary |date=Spring 2009 |volume=V |issue=1 |url=http://americanaejournal.hu/vol5no1/kozlovic |accessdate=July 10, 2019}} Consequently, the name "DeMille" has become synonymous with filmmaking. Publicly Episcopalian, DeMille drew on his Christian and Jewish heritage to convey a message of tolerance.{{cite journal |last1=Kozlovic |first1=Anton K. |title=The Construction of a Christ-figure within the 1956 and 1923 Versions of Cecil B. DeMille's The Ten Commandments |journal=Journal of Religion & Film |date=2016 |volume=10 |issue=1 |page=1 |url=https://digitalcommons.unomaha.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1630&context=jrf |accessdate=May 23, 2019}}{{harvnb|Birchard|2004|p=292}} DeMille received more than a dozen awards from Jewish religious and cultural groups, including [[B'nai B'rith]].{{sfn|Louvish|2007|p=422-423}} However, not everyone received DeMille's religious films favorably. DeMille was accused of antisemitism after the release of ''The King of Kings'',{{sfn|Blanke|2018|p=139}} and director [[John Ford]] despised DeMille for what he saw as "hollow" biblical epics meant to promote DeMille's reputation during the politically turbulent 1950s.{{cite book |last1=Eliot |first1=Marc |title=Jimmy Stewart: A Biography |date=2006 |page=[https://archive.org/details/jimmystewartbiog00elio/page/345 345] |publisher=Harmony Books |location=New York |isbn=9781400052219 |url=https://archive.org/details/jimmystewartbiog00elio/page/345 }} In response to the claims, DeMille donated some of the profits from ''The King of Kings'' to charity.{{cite news |last1=Shales |first1=Tom |title=New Testament to Genius: Turner's "Cecil B. DeMille" |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/2004/04/05/new-testament-to-genius-turners-cecil-b-demille/d1b74aac-7454-4487-b584-3ff56f74ce4f/ |accessdate=July 16, 2019 |work=The Washington Post |date=April 5, 2004}} In the 2012 ''[[Sight & Sound]]'' poll, both DeMille's ''Samson and Delilah'' and 1923 version of ''The Ten Commandments'' received votes, but did not make the top 100 films.{{cite web |title=The International Fillm Magazine, Sight & Sound, All films |url=https://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/sightandsoundpoll2012/films |website=BFI Film Forever |publisher=British Film Institute |accessdate=July 10, 2019}} Although many of DeMille's films are available on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-Ray]] release, only 20 of his silent films are commercially available on DVD {{sfn|Presley|Vieira|2014|pp=404–405}}{{refn|group=note|In the 1950s, Paramount sold its entire pre-1948 film library, including those of DeMille, to [[EMKA]]. Thalberg Memorial Award at the Academy Awards in 1953,{{sfn|Presley|Vieira|2014|p=369}} and a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Directors Guild of America Award the same year.{{cite web |title=5th Annual DGA Awards Honoring Outstanding Directorial Achievement for 1952 |url=https://www.dga.org/Awards/History/1950s/1952.aspx?value=1952 |website=Directors Guild of America |accessdate=May 21, 2019}} In the same ceremony, DeMille received a nomination from Directors Guild of America Award for Outstanding Directorial Achievement in Motion Pictures for ''The Greatest Show on Earth''.{{cite web |title=5th Annual DGA Awards: Honoring Outstanding Directorial Achievement for 1952 |url=https://www.dga.org/Awards/History/1950s/1952.aspx?value=1952 |website=Directors Guild of America |accessdate=May 21, 2019}} In 1952, DeMille was awarded the first Cecil B.
